code:
def prime?(n)
  return false if n <= 1               # non-positive numbers and 1 are not prime
  return true  if n <= 3               # 2 and 3 are prime

  return false if n.even? || n % 3 == 0 # eliminate multiples of 2 and 3 early

  i = 5
  while i * i <= n
    return false if n % i == 0 || n % (i + 2) == 0
    i += 6
  end

  true
end

# Example usage:
# puts prime?(29)   # => true
# puts prime?(30)   # => false

final_answer(answer: "Ruby method `prime?` defined to check primality.")
raw_response:
Thought: Define a Ruby method `prime?` that returns true if the given integer is greater than 1 and has no divisors other than 1 and itself.

```ruby
def prime?(n)
  return false if n <= 1               # non-positive numbers and 1 are not prime
  return true  if n <= 3               # 2 and 3 are prime

  return false if n.even? || n % 3 == 0 # eliminate multiples of 2 and 3 early

  i = 5
  while i * i <= n
    return false if n % i == 0 || n % (i + 2) == 0
    i += 6
  end

  true
end

# Example usage:
# puts prime?(29)   # => true
# puts prime?(30)   # => false

final_answer(answer: "Ruby method `prime?` defined to check primality.")
```
